gauge.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: an instrument for measuring the size or amount of something
gauge.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The petrol gauge is still on full.
gauge.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a measurement of the width or thickness of something such as wire or metal
gauge.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the distance between the lines of a railway or between the wheels of a train
gauge.translation[0].definitions[2].note: broad/narrow gauge (=with more/less than the standard distance between the rails)
gauge.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the width of the barrel of a gun
gauge.translation[0].note_box[0].section: The fuel gauge read a little over half full.
He checked the pressure gauge on the oxygen cylinder.
The oil temperature gauge was twice its normal reading.
A depth gauge is essential for telling you how deep you are when diving.
The gauge showed an abnormal increase in radiation.
gauge.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to judge how people feel about something or what they are likely to do
gauge.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: I looked at Chris, trying to gauge his reaction.
It is difficult to gauge what the other party’s next move will be.
gauge.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to measure or calculate something by using a particular instrument or method
gauge.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The thermostat will gauge the temperature and control the heat.
gauge.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to measure how people feel about something or the effect that something is likely to have on them
gauge.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The magazine commissioned research to gauge opinions on how British industry is meeting its environmental responsibilities.
gauge.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to calculate what is likely to happen in the future, using a particular method or set of figures
gauge.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: US retail sales will help gauge how the economy is faring.
The building society hopes to gauge the likely demand for each property before the auction starts.
gauge.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a measurement of how people feel about something or the effect that something is likely to have on them
gauge.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The survey is an important gauge of attitudes and aspirations among college freshmen.
gauge.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: a method or set of figures that helps to calculate what is likely to happen in the future
gauge.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The government’s economic forecasting gauge rose for the fifth month in a row.
